definition: among

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: There is a need to raise skill levels both amongst those in work and those seeking work.
candidate_match.learner_examples: He was no longer a man amongst others but a man with a free soul... (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

dictionary_examples: There is a need to raise skill levels both amongst those in work and those seeking work.
learner_examples: He was no longer a man amongst others but a man with a free soul... (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

definition: If something is beyond you, you cannot understand it.
dictionary_examples: Computer studies is completely beyond me. | It's beyond me why anyone would want to buy that house.
learner_examples: Lastly, touching upon the subject of the money, how you get the figure of 60% is beyond me, as I have a clear chart of the charity day results. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian)

definition: relating to a particular subject or person

candidate_match.definition: relating to a particular subject or person
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: What's she talking about? | I've got a book about Jung.
candidate_match.learner_examples: I like my IT course becaus[e] I want to learn about computers. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

dictionary_examples: What's she talking about? | I've got a book about Jung.
learner_examples: I like my IT course becaus[e] I want to learn about computers. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

definition: used to show the cause of something, especially a feeling
dictionary_examples: We were surprised at the news. | I was quite excited at the prospect. | Why does no one ever laugh at my jokes?
learner_examples: I was very surprised at my English teacher, as she is an old lady and must be at least seventy years old. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

definition: as said by someone or shown by something
dictionary_examples: According to Sarah, they're not getting on very well at the moment. | According to our records, you owe us £45.
learner_examples: According to the guide, it was a famous culture in ancient times. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: as a result of

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: The train was delayed because of bad weather.
candidate_match.learner_examples: He always had row[s] with his parents because of his school results. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

dictionary_examples: The train was delayed because of bad weather.
learner_examples: He always had row[s] with his parents because of his school results. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

definition: disagreeing with a plan or activity
dictionary_examples: She spoke against the decision to close the college. | Are you for or against the proposal?
learner_examples: It is very hard to keep [a] dog because it makes too much noise and so my Mum is against it. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

definition: used to show the place or position of something
dictionary_examples: She's at home/work. | We met at the station. | We'll meet you at the entrance. | She's sitting at the table in the corner. | She was standing at the top of the stairs. | There's someone at the door. | We spent the afternoon at a football match.
learner_examples: I met [her] at sewing classes. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu)

definition: at or to the back of someone or something
dictionary_examples: Close the door behind you. | Their office is behind the main building.
learner_examples: I think [we should meet] in front of the restaurant, behind the library. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

definition: in the space that separates two places, people or objects
dictionary_examples: The town lies halfway between Rome and Florence. | Standing between the two adults was a small child. | She squeezed between the parked cars and ran out into the road. | A narrow path ran in between the two houses.
learner_examples: The cinema is between Laura's house and the post office. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

definition: on the opposite side of

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: The library is just across the road.
candidate_match.learner_examples: I think you will enjoy it, so let's meet at 6:00 pm at London Bridge Station next to Pret a Manger, because the cinema is just across the road. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: The library is just across the road.
learner_examples: I think you will enjoy it, so let's meet at 6:00 pm at London Bridge Station next to Pret a Manger, because the cinema is just across the road. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: when you have gone past a particular place
dictionary_examples: Turn left after the hotel. | You want the turning on the right just after the police station.
learner_examples: You can go to a wonderful place near here, The Great Falls. This is a very good place because you can [do] extreme sports. It is just after the town, on Main Road. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

definition: following in order
dictionary_examples: H comes after G in the alphabet.

definition: next to and touching something
dictionary_examples: Why don't we put the bed against the wall?
learner_examples: On your left there is a large window and on the right there is a desk between the two cupboards, they are against the wall. (Preliminary English Test; B1; french)

definition: to surround or be on all sides of something, or in a circular movement
dictionary_examples: We sat around the table. | He put his arm around her. | The moon goes around the Earth. | I walked around the building.
learner_examples: You can go around the lake by train. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

definition: to or in different parts of a place
dictionary_examples: I spent a year travelling around Australia. | I used to live around here.
learner_examples: After that, we will walk around the shopping mall. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

definition: about or approximately
dictionary_examples: around two months ago | around four o'clock | She earns around forty thousand a year.
learner_examples: I think I'll arrive around 6.00 p.m. (Key English Test; A2; French)

definition: at a place that you arrive at first when travelling towards another place
dictionary_examples: The hospital is just before the bridge.
learner_examples: Drivers've got often a problem with finding some space and there is another problem - the car park is open just until 8 pm, so the better thin[g] to do is leave a car in car park before the city centre. (First Certificate in English; B2; Czech)

definition: next to someone or something, or very near them

candidate_match.definition: next to someone or something, or very near them
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Come and sit here beside me. | Our school was built right beside a river.
candidate_match.learner_examples: We shall go shopping after the film because the shopping complex is beside the cinema. (Key English Test; A2; Malay)

dictionary_examples: Come and sit here beside me. | Our school was built right beside a river.
learner_examples: We shall go shopping after the film because the shopping complex is beside the cinema. (Key English Test; A2; Malay)

definition: used to show the largest and smallest amount or level of something
dictionary_examples: She weighs between 55 and 60 kilograms. | The competition is open to children between six and twelve years of age.
learner_examples: It's for young people aged between 18 and 30 years old. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Somali)

definition: following someone or something
dictionary_examples: We ran after him but he escaped.
learner_examples: I ran after the bus and shouted to her 'hurry up!' (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

definition: in a line next to or beside something long
dictionary_examples: a row of houses along the river | Cars were parked all along the road.
learner_examples: To my surprise, there was a charming beach along the cycle route. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

definition: in the middle of something
dictionary_examples: I saw a few familiar faces among the crowd. | Rescue teams searched among the ruins for survivors.
learner_examples: If you love nature, you can eat under trees and among flowers. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

definition: in a position in front of someone or something
dictionary_examples: I've never performed this before an audience.

definition: near or next to something or someone
dictionary_examples: A small child stood by her side. | I'll meet you by the post office.
learner_examples: We'll meet by the cinema at 7.00 pm. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish)

definition: used to show a price, temperature, rate, speed, etc.
dictionary_examples: He was driving at 120 mph when the police spotted him.

definition: under something, or in a lower position than something
dictionary_examples: Jeremy hid the letter beneath a pile of papers. | After weeks at sea, it was wonderful to feel firm ground beneath our feet once more.
learner_examples: She could feel the train coming because the ground beneath her feet was moving. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

definition: on the other side of something
dictionary_examples: In the distance, beyond the river, was a small town.
learner_examples: Suddenly she recognized something red, beyond a tree and covered with some leaves. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

definition: involving two or more groups of people
dictionary_examples: Tonight's game is between the New Orleans Saints and the Los Angeles Rams.
learner_examples: I would like to go shopping and then see the football match between Spain and Germany. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: when a time or event has happened
dictionary_examples: Shall we go for a walk after breakfast? | We had a chat after the meeting. | Let's get the shopping. After that, we can stop for a coffee. | After a while, I began to like him. | His birthday is exactly a week after mine. | It was so boring, I left after ten minutes.
learner_examples: You can go shopping, eat [a tasty] meal and after that you can go to the disco and dance all night. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

definition: used to show the time something happens
dictionary_examples: There's a meeting at 2.30 this afternoon. | Are you free at lunchtime? | In theory, women can still have children at the age of 50. | I'm busy at the moment - can you call back later? | At no point did the company do anything illegal.
learner_examples: I go to work at 7.30. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

definition: towards or in the direction of
dictionary_examples: She smiled at me. | They waved at us as we drove by. | "Look at me! Look at me!" called the little girl.
learner_examples: I like walk[ing] around these lakes and look[ing] at ducks and swans. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

definition: the @ symbol, used in email addresses to separate the name of a person, department, etc. from the name of the company
dictionary_examples: dictionary at cambridge dot org

definition: earlier than something or someone
dictionary_examples: two days before the summer holidays | She arrived before me. | You should always wash your hands before meals. | Think hard before accepting the offer.
learner_examples: We will come before 7 o'clock and help you with dinner. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

definition: in the period of time which separates two different events or times
dictionary_examples: You shouldn't eat between meals. | There is a break of ten minutes between classes. | The shop is closed for lunch between 12.30 and 1.30.
learner_examples: I will arrive between 10 o'clock and 11 o'clock. (Key English Test; A2; French)

definition: competing with or opposing someone or something
dictionary_examples: Germany are playing against Brazil in the final tonight.
learner_examples: I like it very much because I can play it [o]n the Internet with all of my friends and I can also form a team to play against other teams in tournaments. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

definition: from one part of a road, river, etc. to another
dictionary_examples: a romantic walk along the beach/river
learner_examples: Last night, we walked along the Thames. (Key English Test; A2; French)

definition: in a particular group of people or things
dictionary_examples: Discuss it among yourselves for a few minutes. | Relax - you're among friends. | There were some good drawings among the rubbish in the pile.
learner_examples: Among my presents, my favourite one is the computer that my parents gave to me. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

definition: connecting two or more places, things or people
dictionary_examples: There is a regular train service between Glasgow and Edinburgh.
learner_examples: We need a motorway link between the motorways 74 and 9. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

definition: separating two places or things
dictionary_examples: The wall between East and West Berlin came down in 1989. | The gap between the rich and the poor has increased dramatically over the past decade.
learner_examples: I think that the most interesting place near my town is [the] mountains [which are] like a wall between my country and China. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

definition: used to show the person or thing that does something
dictionary_examples: She was examined by a doctor. | We were amazed by what she told us. | I'm reading some short stories (written) by Chekhov. | The book was translated by a well-known author.
learner_examples: You have to read the "House of terror" by Constanza Vanges, [which] is about strange things that start happening in a house. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: used to show how something is done
dictionary_examples: They travelled across Europe by train/car. | She did the decorating (all) by herself. | Do you wish to be paid in cash or by cheque? | He learned English by listening to the radio.
learner_examples: You can go there by bus. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

definition: not later than; at/on or before
dictionary_examples: She had promised to be back by five o'clock. | The application must be in by August 31st.
learner_examples: Please come tomorrow by 3 o'clock in the afternoon to paint my bedroom. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: in the opposite direction to
dictionary_examples: Commuting is not so bad when you are travelling against the traffic.
learner_examples: We had to fight against the wind and the rain. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

definition: used after an adjective to show a person's ability to do something
dictionary_examples: I'm not very good at skiing. | He's very talented at maths.
learner_examples: She is really good at tennis. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish)

definition: in front of someone or something in an order or a list
dictionary_examples: The letter K comes before L in the English alphabet.

definition: slower or less successful than someone or something
dictionary_examples: The project is already behind schedule. | Arsenal are six points behind Manchester United with three matches still to play.
learner_examples: Secondly, the show did not start until 20:15 pm. That was almost one hour behind schedule. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

definition: giving your help or support to someone
dictionary_examples: The group is 100 percent behind her.
learner_examples: He is very nice because if you have problems he is always behind you to help you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

definition: in addition to something or someone

candidate_match.definition: in addition to something or someone
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Do you play any other sports besides football and basketball?
candidate_match.learner_examples: It's a Chinese food buffet but besides Chinese food they also have Italian food like pizza. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: Do you play any other sports besides football and basketball?
learner_examples: It's a Chinese food buffet but besides Chinese food they also have Italian food like pizza. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: among two or more people or things
dictionary_examples: We drank two bottles of wine between four of us.
learner_examples: I think you'll have to discuss the ideas between you. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: except

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Everyone but Andrew knows. | This car has been nothing but trouble - it's always breaking down!
candidate_match.learner_examples: I'm free all days of the week but Monday and Wednesday. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: Everyone but Andrew knows. | This car has been nothing but trouble - it's always breaking down!
learner_examples: I'm free all days of the week but Monday and Wednesday. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: in a way that agrees with
dictionary_examples: Students are all put in different groups according to their ability.
learner_examples: The job included organizing suitable activities according to their age, capability and wishes. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

definition: because of something that happened
dictionary_examples: I'll never trust her again after what she did to me.
learner_examples: I really needed those days after what I've been through this spring. (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

definition: at a particular place on a road, river, etc.
dictionary_examples: Somewhere along this road there's a garage.
learner_examples: She told me [that] along the road there are several places to visit, like a castle which is open [to the] public. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

definition: continuing after a particular time or date
dictionary_examples: Few people live beyond the age of a hundred. | We cannot allow the work to continue beyond the end of the year.
learner_examples: You should take a [break] every two hours because, beyond two hours, your mind cannot record what you are learning. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

definition: holding a particular part of someone or something
dictionary_examples: She grabbed me by the arm.

definition: used to show measurements or amounts
dictionary_examples: twelve by ten metres of floor space | Interest rates have been increased by 0.25%. | I'm paid by the hour. | Copies have sold by the million.
learner_examples: Therefore you will see that this festival attracts people by the truckload. (First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch)

definition: despite
dictionary_examples: I can't believe he was so rude to you after all the help you've given him!
learner_examples: But, even after earning more in 2001, the women still do not earn as much [as] men on average earned (£20,363) in 1997. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Gujarati)

definition: while something else is happening
dictionary_examples: Security was increased amid fears of further terrorist attacks.
learner_examples: They are involved so much with their occupation that they will respond to an emergency call even when they are amid sweet dreams or having a joyful time with their love[d] ones. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu)

definition: to each one in a group
dictionary_examples: She divided the cake among the children.
learner_examples: Although Brazil is the eighth biggest economy in the world and one of the richest countries regarding natural resources, that wealth is not shared equally among the population. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese)

definition: causing something, or responsible for something
dictionary_examples: What was the reason behind her decision to leave?
learner_examples: Another reason behind this kind of thinking is that some boys feel a[w]kward when they see girls and they think they are being ignored in the class. (International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi)

definition: involving or affecting other things or people than the ones you have talked about
dictionary_examples: You should try to develop interests beyond the family.
learner_examples: Of course, the process of women['s] liberation isn't viewed with enthusiasm by husbands who would have to wash up and cook if their wives wanted to develop women interests beyond their family circle. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

definition: used when giving someone or something the same name as another person or thing
dictionary_examples: It was called the Biko building, after the famous South African.
learner_examples: I called her Lena after my sister. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

definition: among
dictionary_examples: a village set amid rolling hills
learner_examples: So we are mere fading stars [i]n a huge sky, unsubjected to the elapse of time and instead of following the ancient saying "carpe diem", we get lost amid other stars. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian)

definition: treated as more important than someone or something
dictionary_examples: They always put the children's needs before their own.
learner_examples: She puts people with their needs before her own comfort, that is why she is successful. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

definition: If a bad experience or your own bad behaviour is behind you, it does not exist or affect your life now.
dictionary_examples: He's put his criminal past behind him.
learner_examples: We have got to put the past behind us. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

definition: If someone or something is beneath you, you think you are too important or from too high a social class to spend time on them.
dictionary_examples: He thinks housework is beneath him.
learner_examples: He hadn't realised how much he would miss the high-life until he was forced to watch all the rich and famous people come into the restaurant and look down [on] everything and everyone who was beneath them. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

definition: about

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: I've had a letter from the tax authorities concerning my tax payments.
candidate_match.learner_examples: I am writing in reply to your letter concerning the prize I won in your competition, which is two weeks at Camp California in the U.S.A. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

dictionary_examples: I've had a letter from the tax authorities concerning my tax payments.
learner_examples: I am writing in reply to your letter concerning the prize I won in your competition, which is two weeks at Camp California in the U.S.A. (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

definition: used for saying that you have a particular opinion about something, because of a particular fact about it

candidate_match.definition: used for saying that you have a particular opinion about something, because of a particular fact about it
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: She did really well, considering how little experience she'd had. | Considering the weather, we got here quite quickly.
candidate_match.learner_examples: Considering all the above, I think that your article was completely misleading. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

dictionary_examples: She did really well, considering how little experience she'd had. | Considering the weather, we got here quite quickly.
learner_examples: Considering all the above, I think that your article was completely misleading. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

definition: used to say that something happened or is true, although something else makes this seem not probable

candidate_match.definition: used to say that something happened or is true, although something else makes this seem not probable
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: I still enjoyed the week despite the weather. | Despite claims that the product is safe, many people have stopped buying it. | He managed to eat a big lunch despite having eaten an enormous breakfast.
candidate_match.learner_examples: Despite having to share a bedroom with my three cousins, I feel very comfortable. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: I still enjoyed the week despite the weather. | Despite claims that the product is safe, many people have stopped buying it. | He managed to eat a big lunch despite having eaten an enormous breakfast.
learner_examples: Despite having to share a bedroom with my three cousins, I feel very comfortable. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: in or towards a low or lower position, from a higher one
dictionary_examples: I slid down the hill. | Aikiko fell down some stairs and broke her wrist.
learner_examples: I was the first to go down the hill. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: along or further along
dictionary_examples: We drove down the motorway as far as Bristol. | Her office is down the corridor on the right. | They sailed the boat down the river.
learner_examples: Then we went down the Nile by boat. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

definition: for the whole of a period of time
dictionary_examples: They work during the night and sleep by day. | There were huge advances in aviation technology during World War Two.
learner_examples: We sat together during the lesson. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

definition: at some time between the beginning and the end of a period
dictionary_examples: I woke up several times during the night. | The programme will be shown on television during the weekend.
learner_examples: I'm going to see them during this holiday. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese)

definition: not including a particular fact, thing or person

candidate_match.definition: not including a particular fact, thing or person
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: The museum is open daily except Mondays. | It's cool and quiet everywhere except in the kitchen. | Everyone was there except for Sally.
candidate_match.learner_examples: All of my friends came except you. (Key English Test; A2; Bengali)

dictionary_examples: The museum is open daily except Mondays. | It's cool and quiet everywhere except in the kitchen. | Everyone was there except for Sally.
learner_examples: All of my friends came except you. (Key English Test; A2; Bengali)

definition: wearing
dictionary_examples: Do you recognize that man in the grey suit? | She's always dressed in red.
learner_examples: [T]he man has to be dressed in black. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: showing meaning
dictionary_examples: What's the Czech word for 'book'? | "What does J.L. stand for?" "José Luis."

definition: expressed or written in a particular way
dictionary_examples: They spoke in Russian the whole time. | Why not do a rough answer in pencil first? | Complete the form in (black) ink.
learner_examples: I also speak in English during the break. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

definition: in support of or in agreement with
dictionary_examples: I voted for the Greens at the last election. | So let's hear some applause for these talented young performers.
learner_examples: There are a lot of votes for and against keeping animals in cages. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

definition: used to show the place where someone or something starts
dictionary_examples: What time does the flight from Amsterdam arrive? | The wind is coming from the north. | She sent me a postcard from Majorca. | She took her hairbrush from her handbag and began to brush her hair. | So did you really walk all the way from Bond Street?
learner_examples: My favourite one is the present from Lily. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

definition: used to show the origin of someone or something
dictionary_examples: "Where are you from?" "I'm from Italy." | I come from Spain. | I wonder who this card is from.
learner_examples: She comes from Poland. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Panjabi)

definition: inside or towards the inside of a container, place or area
dictionary_examples: There's milk in the fridge. | Is Mark still in bed? | They live in an old cottage. | How much is that coat in the window? | What's that in your hand? | They used to live in Paris, but now they're somewhere in Italy. | My daughter's in hospital overnight.
learner_examples: He works in Austria now. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Singhalese)

definition: in or into a room, building, container, etc.
dictionary_examples: There were some keys inside the box.
learner_examples: I kept it inside the jewel box. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

definition: towards the inside or middle of something
dictionary_examples: He's gone into a shop across the road. | Shall we go into the garden? | Stop running around and get into bed!
learner_examples: I will sweep the floor and clean around my bed, [and] put the waste into the bin. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

definition: used to show the material of which something is made
dictionary_examples: juice made from oranges and mangoes
learner_examples: The present I love[d] the most was a cute little cat that [is] made from glass. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

definition: forming a part of something
dictionary_examples: He used to be the lead singer in a rock band. | There are too many spelling mistakes in this essay. | I've been waiting in this queue for ages.
learner_examples: My sister sings in a pop group. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

definition: arranged or divided in a particular way
dictionary_examples: We all sat down in a circle. | The desks were arranged in rows of ten. | Discounts are available to people travelling in large groups. | The books on these shelves are arranged in alphabetical order.
learner_examples: We often work in groups where we can talk in English. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

definition: used to show the position of something in comparison with other things, or the point of view of someone when considering a matter or problem
dictionary_examples: From the restaurant there is a beautiful view of Siena. | She was talking from her own experience of the problem. | From our point of view, we do not see how these changes will benefit the company.
learner_examples: The job was hard, but from my point of view, it was worth [it]. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

definition: experiencing an emotion or condition
dictionary_examples: She's in a bad/good mood this morning. | You're in great danger. | He's living in luxury in the south of France.
learner_examples: I hope you are in a good mood today, because we are planning to go to Cinepolis. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: in exchange for something, especially an amount of money
dictionary_examples: How much did you pay for your glasses? | She sold the house for quite a lot of money. | They've said they'll repair my car for £300.
learner_examples: I['m] sell[ing] it for 100 Euro. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

definition: being employed by or representing a company, country, etc.
dictionary_examples: She works for a charity. | He plays football for Cambridge United. | He used to swim for his country when he was younger.
learner_examples: He works for a company in Mexico. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

definition: used to show that a person or thing is part of a larger group, amount or process

candidate_match.definition: used to show that a person or thing is part of a larger group, amount or process
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Eight people, including two children, were injured in the explosion. | It's £24.99, including postage.
candidate_match.learner_examples: [At] my party we danced a lot and everybody was there, including Amanda, Bruna, and Paola. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: Eight people, including two children, were injured in the explosion. | It's £24.99, including postage.
learner_examples: [At] my party we danced a lot and everybody was there, including Amanda, Bruna, and Paola. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: after or as a result of

candidate_match.definition: after or as a result of
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Following the dinner, there will be a dance. | He died on October 23rd, following several years of illness.
candidate_match.learner_examples: Following the course in England, I worked in an office that sells computer programs and games as a secretary to earn money and with the help of this job, I gained experience in office work. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

dictionary_examples: Following the dinner, there will be a dance. | He died on October 23rd, following several years of illness.
learner_examples: Following the course in England, I worked in an office that sells computer programs and games as a secretary to earn money and with the help of this job, I gained experience in office work. (First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish)

definition: intended to be given to or used by someone or something
dictionary_examples: There's a phone message for you. | I'd better buy something for the new baby.
learner_examples: This is my information for you. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

definition: used to show an amount of time or distance
dictionary_examples: She's out of the office for a few days next week. | I'm just going to rest for an hour or so. | I haven't played tennis for years. | We drove for miles without seeing anyone.
learner_examples: I had a break for 20 minutes. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

definition: used to show the time when something starts or the time when it was made or first existed
dictionary_examples: Drinks will be served from seven o'clock. | The price of petrol will rise by 5p a gallon from tomorrow. | Most of the paintings in this room date from the seventeenth century. | The museum is open from 9.30 to 6.00 Tuesday to Sunday.
learner_examples: It's from 5:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: used to show the distance between two places
dictionary_examples: It's about two kilometres from the airport to your hotel. | We're about a mile from home.
learner_examples: I[t']s about 3 kilometres from the city centre. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

definition: during part or all of a period of time
dictionary_examples: We're going to Italy in April. | I started working here in 2007. | Life in the 19th century was very different from what it is now. | She was a brilliant gymnast in her youth. | I haven't had a decent night's sleep in years/ages.
learner_examples: I like my country in March because spring is coming. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish)

definition: having a particular purpose
dictionary_examples: There's a sign there saying 'boats for hire'. | Which vitamins should you take for skin problems?
learner_examples: You [need] to bring your exer[c]ise book for art. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

definition: in order to get or achieve something
dictionary_examples: I hate waiting for public transport. | I had to run for the bus. | Did you send off for details of the competition? | I've applied for a job with another computer company.
learner_examples: It's important to me because I['m] going to study for an exam. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: on the occasion of
dictionary_examples: What did you buy him for Christmas? | We're having a party for Jim's 60th birthday.
learner_examples: I'm tired because I ha[d] a party yesterday for my birthday. (Key English Test; A2; French)

definition: at a particular time
dictionary_examples: I've booked a table at the restaurant for nine o'clock. | We can give you an appointment for 10.15.
learner_examples: Can we rearrange the time for five o'clock? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

definition: because of or as a result of something
dictionary_examples: He got fined for travelling without a ticket. | The things you do for love! | Scotland is famous for its beautiful countryside. | He's best remembered for his novels.
learner_examples: It is famous for "paella" but we have many dif[f]erent kind[s] of food. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish)

definition: towards or in the direction of
dictionary_examples: They looked as if they were heading for the train station. | Just follow signs for the town centre. | This time tomorrow we'll be setting off for the States. | It says this train is for Birmingham and Coventry only.

definition: needing or using no more time than a particular amount of time
dictionary_examples: Can you finish the job in two weeks? | Dinner will be ready in ten minutes. | She could get that essay done in a couple of hours if she really tried.
learner_examples: My bedroom isn't too big, so we will finish in 1 hour. (Key English Test; A2; Thai)

definition: used to show when a person or thing changes from one form or condition to another
dictionary_examples: Peel the cucumber and chop it into small cubes. | Her novels have been translated into nineteen languages. | We're planning to turn the smallest bedroom into an office.
learner_examples: I like it very much because now I can convert any language into Bengali. (Key English Test; A2; Bengali)

definition: in order to help someone
dictionary_examples: I'll carry those bags for you.
learner_examples: I'd like to do something helpful for them. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

definition: used when you are saying how similar or different two things, people or places are
dictionary_examples: University is very different from school. | His opinion could hardly be more different from mine. | The two sisters are so similar that it's almost impossible to tell one from the other.
learner_examples: His clothes are very different from everyone else['s]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

definition: involved or connected with a particular subject or activity
dictionary_examples: a degree in philosophy | advances in medical science | I never knew you worked in publishing.
learner_examples: He is my age and we have the same tastes in music and art. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: in place of

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: You can go instead of me, if you want. | We should book the flights now instead of waiting until next week.
candidate_match.learner_examples: I had to admit that I would prefer to go with my friends and I decided to go with them instead of being with my parents. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese)

dictionary_examples: You can go instead of me, if you want. | We should book the flights now instead of waiting until next week.
learner_examples: I had to admit that I would prefer to go with my friends and I decided to go with them instead of being with my parents. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese)

definition: moving towards something or someone and hitting them
dictionary_examples: He's always walking into things when he hasn't got his glasses on.
learner_examples: Then I bumped into a man... What a surprise! [It] was Thom Yorke. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

definition: in the direction of something or someone
dictionary_examples: She was looking straight into his eyes.
learner_examples: I turned around and looked into the eyes of my favourite football player Timo Hildebrand. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

definition: used to show the cause of something or the reason why something happens
dictionary_examples: He was rushed to hospital but died from his injuries. | You could tell she wasn't lying from the fear in her voice.
learner_examples: Many people have died from car accidents. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

definition: used to show a change in the state of someone or something
dictionary_examples: Things went from bad to worse. | She has been promoted from manager to director.
learner_examples: On the other hand the number of animals living in freedom, for example the number of tigers, elephants and lions in Africa or Asia, is decreasing more and more, because their living conditions have gone from bad to worse. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

definition: used to show what someone is not allowed to do or know, or what has been stopped happening
dictionary_examples: He's been banned from driving for six months. | For many years, the truth was kept from the public.
learner_examples: Wouldn't it be better if cars were banned from the Central Business District in order to avoid traffic jams and stress[?] (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

definition: used when referring to something that is done as a result of something else
dictionary_examples: I'd like to do something for you in return/exchange for everything you've done for me. | The changes are in response to demand from our customers. | He refused to say anything in reply to the journalists' questions.
learner_examples: I am writing to you in response to your advertisement of 1st December in the Times. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

definition: used to say whose responsibility something is
dictionary_examples: I can't tell you whether you should go or not - that's for you to decide.
learner_examples: It is for you to decide whet[h]er my colleagues should take part in this kind of course or not, but all in all I would like to recommend this course. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

definition: when compared to a particular fact
dictionary_examples: She's quite tall for her age.
learner_examples: She spends all day indoors "stuffing" her craving for knowledge with books quite hard for her age. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian)

definition: used to show when doing one thing is the cause of another thing happening
dictionary_examples: In refusing to work abroad, she missed an excellent job opportunity. | The government banned tobacco advertising and, in doing so, contributed greatly to the nation's health.
learner_examples: According to Montaigne's point of view, children and even "older" people ought to travel as much as possible. In doing so, they would receive an education that no school could provide them with. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

definition: in less than a particular length of time
dictionary_examples: The doctor's promised to be here inside an hour.
learner_examples: You can reach two stations on the tube-line seven inside 10 minutes; in addition there are two bus-stops even closer. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

definition: used to show the way in which something is recorded or broadcast
dictionary_examples: What's on television tonight? | When's the film coming out on DVD?
learner_examples: At the party, we watched films on television. (Key English Test; A2; French)

definition: used to show the reason why someone does something
dictionary_examples: I took the job out of necessity because we had no money left. | Just out of interest, how much did it cost you? | I only went there out of curiosity.
learner_examples: When the warrior had left, the explorer [explored the cave] out of curiosity and [to] his big surprise found the treasure. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

definition: close in distance
dictionary_examples: Is there a train station near here? | We were near the exit. | The hotel is near the airport. | Don't come too near me - you might catch my cold. | Which bus stop is nearest (to) your house? | I moved my chair nearer to the fire.
learner_examples: The park is near my house, about 10 minutes on foot. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

definition: used after words which show an amount
dictionary_examples: a kilo of apples | loads of food | hundreds of people | most of them | none of them | both of us | a third of all people | a drop of rain
learner_examples: She has a lot of flowers in her room. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

definition: containing
dictionary_examples: a bag of sweets | a bottle of beer | a book of short stories | sacks of rubbish
learner_examples: I like cups of tea, I like noodles, but I don't like beef. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Mandarin)

definition: used with numbers, ages and dates
dictionary_examples: an essay of 500 words | a boy of six | the 14th of February 2005
learner_examples: The class started [on] the 2nd of June at half past five. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: on or onto a surface
dictionary_examples: Ouch, you're standing on my foot! | I dropped my pen on the floor. | Look at all the books on your desk! | We put all of our medicine on a high shelf. | Your suitcase is on top of the wardrobe.
learner_examples: I can read the book, listen to music, watch TV or just sit on my sofa and drink a hot [cup of] tea. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

definition: covering, touching, attached to or hanging from something
dictionary_examples: You've got blood on your shirt. | Which finger do you wear your ring on? | We could hang this picture on the wall next to the door. | Dogs should be kept on their leads at all times.
learner_examples: I like my bedroom, because there are [a] lot of windows, two armchair[s], a lamp next to the bed, a table under the window, [and] some pictures on the wall. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

definition: very close to something or someone, with nothing in between

candidate_match.definition: very close to something or someone, with nothing in between
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Come and sit next to me. | The factory is right next to a residential area.
candidate_match.learner_examples: I left it in your bedroom, next to your desk. (Key English Test; A2; French)

dictionary_examples: Come and sit next to me. | The factory is right next to a residential area.
learner_examples: I left it in your bedroom, next to your desk. (Key English Test; A2; French)

definition: used in expressions showing position
dictionary_examples: the top of his head | the back of your dress | on the corner of the street | the front of the queue | I've never been north of Edinburgh.
learner_examples: First you [go] pas[t] [a] big supermarket on the corner of my street. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish)

definition: showing someone or something
dictionary_examples: a map of the city centre | a photo of my boyfriend
learner_examples: Tony gave me a photo of Henry. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

definition: used to refer to a place when giving directions
dictionary_examples: Our house is the first on the left after the post office. | Take the first turning on the right.
learner_examples: My house is the first one on the left. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak)

definition: in a particular place
dictionary_examples: the diagram on page 22 | They lived on a farm.
learner_examples: I live on a farm in the Emmental. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

definition: in a position facing someone or something but on the other side

candidate_match.definition: in a position facing someone or something but on the other side
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: We're in the building opposite the library. | They sat opposite each other. | Put a tick opposite the answer that you think is correct.
candidate_match.learner_examples: It's near the park and opposite the bank, so it isn't far. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

dictionary_examples: We're in the building opposite the library. | They sat opposite each other. | Put a tick opposite the answer that you think is correct.
learner_examples: It's near the park and opposite the bank, so it isn't far. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

definition: no longer in a particular place or area
dictionary_examples: Take the main road out of the city. | He has been out of the country for a long time.
learner_examples: When you arrive please come to my home and then we can go there because it's out of the city. (Key English Test; A2; Turkish)

definition: not in a particular room, building or place, but near it

candidate_match.definition: not in a particular room, building or place, but near it
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: She waited outside his room for nearly two hours. | He lives just outside Birmingham.
candidate_match.learner_examples: I'll meet you outside the art class. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

dictionary_examples: She waited outside his room for nearly two hours. | He lives just outside Birmingham.
learner_examples: I'll meet you outside the art class. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

definition: more than a particular amount, number, or age
dictionary_examples: Most of the bikes cost/are over £300. | Children over the age of 12 must have full-price tickets. | They are already $25 million over budget.
learner_examples: We have to dance in a school and over two hundred people [will watch] us. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

definition: used to show who or what does something
dictionary_examples: the works of Shakespeare | the arrival of the rainy season | the music of the flute
learner_examples: They often cover the music of "The Beatles" or "The Rolling Stones". (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

definition: next to or along the side of a place or area
dictionary_examples: Cambridge is on the River Cam. | Our house was on Sturton Street. | Strasbourg is on the border of France and Germany.
learner_examples: Dan, We are going to the cinema that is on Arocena street. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: used to show movement away from the inside of a place or container
dictionary_examples: A peach rolled out of the bag. | I jumped out of bed and ran downstairs.
learner_examples: Once he told me that he and his other friend saw a cat falling out of a window. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

definition: from among an amount or number
dictionary_examples: Nine out of ten people said they liked the product. | No one got 20 out of 20 in the test.
learner_examples: He got 99.4 out of 100, "Oh my God". (Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek)

definition: above or higher than something
dictionary_examples: The sign over the door said "Exit". | A flock of geese flew over the trees. | She held the umbrella over both of us.
learner_examples: Besides that, you have voted for the construction of a new bridge over the main street. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

definition: on the other side of
dictionary_examples: There's a pub over the road we could go to. | The story continues over the page. |  The station is over the bridge.

definition: used for showing some methods of travelling
dictionary_examples: I love travelling on trains. | She'll be arriving on the five-thirty bus. | We went to France on the ferry.
learner_examples: I will travel on a train and then I will take [a] taxi to your home. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

definition: belonging or relating to someone or something
dictionary_examples: a friend of mine | the colour of her hair | part of the problem | employees of the company
learner_examples: The name of my friend is Maria. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

definition: used to show the day or date when something happens
dictionary_examples: Many shops don't open on Sundays. | What are you doing on Friday? | My birthday's on the 30th of May.
learner_examples: I go to college on Monday and Wednesday. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

definition: similar to or in the same way as someone or something
dictionary_examples: She's very much like her mother. | Is Japanese food anything like Chinese? | I've got a sweater just like that. | Her hair was so soft it was like silk.
learner_examples: After the game, we had a barbecue and I met Theresa, a very good-looking girl who is interested in politics, just like me. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

definition: reduced by a stated number

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Five minus three is two. | That will be £1500, minus the deposit of £150 that you have already paid. | The temperature fell to minus 20 overnight.
candidate_match.learner_examples: It's cold [in] winter: minus ten degrees! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

dictionary_examples: Five minus three is two. | That will be £1500, minus the deposit of £150 that you have already paid. | The temperature fell to minus 20 overnight.
learner_examples: It's cold [in] winter: minus ten degrees! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak)

definition: used when comparing related things
dictionary_examples: Best of all I liked the green one. | Worst of all was the food! | He's the best looking of the three brothers. | I think that of all his films it's my favourite.
learner_examples: The best of all was a necklace. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

definition: used to show what money or time is used for
dictionary_examples: She refuses to spend more than £20 on a pair of shoes. | I've wasted too much time on this already.
learner_examples: I love it and I spend all my time on it. (Key English Test; A2; Greek)

definition: covering something or someone
dictionary_examples: Put a blanket over you to keep warm. | I put my hands over my eyes because I didn't want to see.
learner_examples: Wear an apron over your clothes. (Key English Test; A2; Hindi)

definition: such as
dictionary_examples: She looks best in bright colours, like red and pink.
learner_examples: We have visit[ed] beautiful places like Chile, Patagonia, Iguazu. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

definition: showing a reason or cause
dictionary_examples: He died of cancer.
learner_examples: But, three months later, after walk[ing] in the rain he died of pneumonia. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

definition: down or away from a place or position
dictionary_examples: All the leaves had dropped off the tree. | He fell off his bike.
learner_examples: I still remember the way your brother fell off the lad[d]er that day. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

definition: used with actions in which something is removed or removes itself from another thing
dictionary_examples: I can't get the lid off this jar. | Has anyone taken a book off my desk? | Could you cut me a small piece off that white cheese? | Take your feet off the seat.
learner_examples: Next month, I'm going to change my bedroom. I'll take the photographs off the wall. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: about
dictionary_examples: a book on plants | Her thesis is on Italian women's literature.
learner_examples: The other one is a book on dogs and cats. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

definition: using something
dictionary_examples: I do all my household accounts on computer. | Chris is on drums and Mike's on bass guitar. | I'm on the phone.
learner_examples: I was in the pizza shop to order some food for my family and I was on the phone. (Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Farsi)

definition: used to show movement into or on a particular place
dictionary_examples: I slipped as I stepped onto the platform. | The crates were loaded onto trucks.
learner_examples: We couldn't talk so much, because the music was very loud till a group of singers came onto the dance floor and [did] a great show. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

definition: used to show what something is made from
dictionary_examples: The dress is made out of silk. | The statue was carved out of a single block of stone.
learner_examples: I love clothes which are made out of cotton. These are perfect for this hot weather. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil)

definition: across from one side of something to the other, especially by going up and then down
dictionary_examples: She jumped over the gate. | The road goes over the mountains. | She is always chatting with her neighbour over the garden fence. | From the top of the tower you could see for miles over the city. | Tanks travel over the most difficult ground.
learner_examples: I most enjoyed [it] when we [were] cycling over the hills, because there weren't any people and it was peaceful and qui[et]. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German)

definition: during a particular period of time
dictionary_examples: I was in Seattle over the summer. | We discussed the matter over lunch. | It's fascinating to watch how a baby changes and develops over time.
learner_examples: He apologised for the trouble and when he heard that they just wanted to stay over the weekend, he said they should go and buy the most important things and enjoy the weekend as the suitcase wo[uld]n't arrive until Monday. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

definition: typical or characteristic of
dictionary_examples: That's just like Maisie to turn up half an hour late to her own party! | It's not like you to be so quiet - are you all right?

definition: close in time
dictionary_examples: He arrived near the end of the lesson. | It was nearer four when we finally arrived. | We can decide which route to take nearer the time.

definition: used after an adjective when judging someone's behaviour
dictionary_examples: It was very nice of you to think of us. | It was a bit mean of him to mention her weight. | Thank you so much for my present. How thoughtful of you.
learner_examples: It was most thoughtful of you to invite us and I warmly appreciate your hospitality. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

definition: near to a building or place
dictionary_examples: an island off the coast of Spain
learner_examples: He spent all night off the coast, (unfinished) (First Certificate in English; B2; Russian)

definition: used to show what happens as a result of touching or hitting against something
dictionary_examples: You'll cut yourself on that knife if you're not careful. | I hit my head on the shelf as I was standing up.
learner_examples: Suddenly I hit my head on the bed as the man was talking. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

definition: used to show something which is used as food or fuel
dictionary_examples: What do frogs live on? | Does this radio run on batteries?
learner_examples: All new cars run on unleaded fuel w[h]ich is a benefit to the environment. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

definition: used to show that you are starting to talk about a different subject
dictionary_examples: How did we get onto this subject?
learner_examples: Let's move onto another topic! (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

definition: no longer in a particular condition or situation
dictionary_examples: The patient is now out of danger.
learner_examples: She told me that D was out of danger and that she will have other information tomorrow. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

definition: using
dictionary_examples: They spoke over the phone. | We heard the news over the radio.
learner_examples: She laughed over the phone, and said "It's really like you". (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

definition: because of

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: The concert has been cancelled owing to low ticket sales.
candidate_match.learner_examples: To start with, [it] is a great idea to change rooms because the[y] are too crowded, owing to the fact that there a lot of people. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

dictionary_examples: The concert has been cancelled owing to low ticket sales.
learner_examples: To start with, [it] is a great idea to change rooms because the[y] are too crowded, owing to the fact that there a lot of people. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

definition: about or relating to
dictionary_examples: Speaking of Elizabeth, here she is. | Let us consider the events of the last five months. | We know very little of her childhood.
learner_examples: Speaking of sightseeing, many thought that visiting other sights - like the Folk Museum - should not be compulsory. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish)

definition: almost in a particular state or condition
dictionary_examples: The runners looked near exhaustion. | I was near (to) tears at one point during the film. | This is the nearest I've ever got to winning anything. | He came near to punching him.
learner_examples: It is strictly related to the fact that the old possess a vast amount of experience and are nearer to death. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

definition: in control of or teaching someone or something
dictionary_examples: A good teacher has an easy authority over a class. | She's a sales manager but she has a regional sales director over her. | The victory over the French at Waterloo was Wellington's greatest triumph.
learner_examples: Fortunately, my parents do not wield authority over me and my siblings like dictators. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

definition: connected with or about
dictionary_examples: It's stupid arguing over something so trivial.
learner_examples: The teams themselves suffered from these money problems: recently strikes broke out in basketball teams in the U.S when players began to argue over money. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

definition: about

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: The company is being questioned regarding its employment policy.
candidate_match.learner_examples: I apologise to you for missing tomorrow's class as I have to attend a meeting regarding the field trip for our school with the Principal. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Malayalam)

dictionary_examples: The company is being questioned regarding its employment policy.
learner_examples: I apologise to you for missing tomorrow's class as I have to attend a meeting regarding the field trip for our school with the Principal. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Malayalam)

definition: in or to a position that is further than a particular point
dictionary_examples: I live on Station Road, just past the post office. | Three boys went past us on mountain bikes. | Was that Peter who just jogged past in those bright pink shorts?
learner_examples: Turn right past the store and turn left ok? (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: surrounding or being on all sides of something, or in a circular movement
dictionary_examples: We sat round the fire. | I put my arm round her. |  She had a scarf round her neck.  | The Moon goes round the Earth.
learner_examples: There [is] a big wood round this lake. (Key English Test; A2; Hungarian)

definition: used to say what the time is when it is a particular number of minutes after an hour
dictionary_examples: It's 5/10/a quarter/20/25/half past three. | I've got to leave at twenty past or I'll miss that train.
learner_examples: The class started the 2nd of June at half past five. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: for each

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: The meal will cost $20 per person. | The car was travelling at 70 miles per hour (70 mph). | There are more cafés per square mile here than anywhere else in the country.
candidate_match.learner_examples: It's two hours per lesson. (Key English Test; A2; French)

dictionary_examples: The meal will cost $20 per person. | The car was travelling at 70 miles per hour (70 mph). | There are more cafés per square mile here than anywhere else in the country.
learner_examples: It's two hours per lesson. (Key English Test; A2; French)

definition: added to

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: What is six plus four? | The rent will be £75 a week, plus gas and electricity. | There will be two adults travelling, plus three children.
candidate_match.learner_examples: Finally, does the offer include two free meals in the restaurant plus breakfast? (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

dictionary_examples: What is six plus four? | The rent will be £75 a week, plus gas and electricity. | There will be two adults travelling, plus three children.
learner_examples: Finally, does the offer include two free meals in the restaurant plus breakfast? (First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish)

definition: to or in different parts of a place
dictionary_examples: The landlord showed me round the house. | I had to go all round town to find a hotel that was open.
learner_examples: Well, she showed me round her hometown and we did some sight-seeing. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

definition: above a particular age or further than a particular point
dictionary_examples: This meat is past its sell-by date. | She's past the age where she needs a babysitter.

definition: used to show who receives something or experiences an action
dictionary_examples: I gave the money to my sister. | Give the gun to me. |  Anna was speaking to her mother on the phone.  | I lent my bike to my brother. | Who's the letter addressed to?
learner_examples: Please bring it to me tomorrow, because I have to return it to my brother. (Key English Test; A2; Portuguese)

definition: in relation to something or someone
dictionary_examples: They've always been very friendly towards me. | He feels a lot of anger towards his father. | She always has a positive attitude towards life.
learner_examples: His parents were very cold towards me. (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

definition: used to talk about a place or an event where someone goes
dictionary_examples: We went to Prague last year. | We could go to town on the bus. | I have to go to the dentist this morning. | We received another invitation to a wedding this morning. | I've asked Helen and Ben to dinner next week. | You can walk from here to the station in under ten minutes. | She walked over to the window. | He went up to a complete stranger and started talking.
learner_examples: I like go[ing] to London. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese)

definition: from one end or side of something to the other
dictionary_examples: We drove through the tunnel. |  The River Seine flows through Paris.  |  The sun was shining through the window.  |  She cut through the wire.  | They walked slowly through the woods.
learner_examples: So, through the windows I can see [the sea] and it is wonderful. (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

definition: used to show the position of someone or something
dictionary_examples: She stood with her back to the window.  | I had my back to them, so I couldn't see what they were doing. | John's standing to the left of Adrian in the photo. | The Yorkshire Dales are twenty miles to the north of the city.
learner_examples: My town is situated to the south of Paris. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

definition: in every part of a place
dictionary_examples: The same laws apply throughout much of Europe.
learner_examples: Being the owner of [a] driving licence has become a dream [for the] majority of young, middle-aged or even elderly people throughout the world. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

definition: used to show a relationship with someone
dictionary_examples: I've been married to Peter for nine years. | She was an assistant to the chief executive.
learner_examples: She's 38 years old and she's married to a Spanish engineer. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

definition: used to compare two different things or amounts
dictionary_examples: My son is a lot taller than my daughter. | You always walk faster than I do! | You're earlier than usual.
learner_examples: Cirencester is smaller than Swindon. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Romanian)

definition: used to say 'before' the hour when you are saying what time it is
dictionary_examples: It's five to three.

definition: from a time in the past until a later time or until now

candidate_match.definition: from a time in the past until a later time or until now
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: England have not won the World Cup in football since 1966. | It was the hottest October since records began.

dictionary_examples: England have not won the World Cup in football since 1966. | It was the hottest October since records began.

definition: used with 'more' or 'less' to compare numbers or amounts
dictionary_examples: I spent more than I intended to. | It cost less than I expected.
learner_examples: I want to sell my "English Grammar" book, it's a great book, simple to read, just the right book for you, and I [am] sell[ing] it at less than half price; INCREDIBLE!! (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

definition: until

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: We waited till half past six for you. |  Up till 1918, women in Britain were not allowed to vote.
candidate_match.learner_examples: I am going to be busy till 10:30 am. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

dictionary_examples: We waited till half past six for you. |  Up till 1918, women in Britain were not allowed to vote.
learner_examples: I am going to be busy till 10:30 am. (Key English Test; A2; Tamil)

definition: from the start to the end of something
dictionary_examples: He worked through the night.  |  The phone rang halfway through the programme.
learner_examples: It begins in the evening and goes through the night, because it's a very long play. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

definition: because of someone or something, or with someone's help
dictionary_examples: I got the job through a friend of my mum's.  |  He became ill through eating undercooked meat.
learner_examples: I knew her through my husband, she is my husband's friend's wife. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

definition: used to say who is treated in a particular way or who or what is affected by something
dictionary_examples: What have you done to your hair? | Her evidence was very helpful to the police. | She was very kind to us.
learner_examples: The waiter was really kind to us. We gave him the key of the car and he drove us home. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

definition: used to compare two things
dictionary_examples: I prefer football to cricket.  | She's earning a reasonable wage, but nothing to what she could make in a big company.
learner_examples: I prefer homemade food to re[s]taurant meals. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian)

definition: until a particular time, state or level is reached
dictionary_examples: It's only two weeks to Christmas. | Unemployment has risen to almost eight million. | She nursed me back to health.

definition: used to say where something is fastened or connected
dictionary_examples: The paper was fastened to the wall with tape. | A fast rail service connects us to the city.
learner_examples: My mouth became so dry that my tongue stuck to my palate. (First Certificate in English; B2; French)

definition: in the direction of someone or something
dictionary_examples: She stood up and walked towards him. | He leaned towards his wife and whispered, "Can we go home soon?" | She kept glancing towards the telephone.
learner_examples: We took the train from Paris to Bordeaux, and from there we started to cycle towards the sea. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

definition: during the whole of a period of time
dictionary_examples: He yawned throughout the performance.
learner_examples: This teahouse is packed throughout [the] day with workers and retired people, who come to sip tea, talk, and watch the endless stream of passers-by in the old city of China. (First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese)

definition: multiplied by

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: What is eight times fourteen?

dictionary_examples: What is eight times fourteen?

definition: used in phrases which show a range
dictionary_examples: There must have been thirty to thirty-five people there.

definition: near to a time or place
dictionary_examples: Our seats were towards the back of the theatre. | I often get hungry towards the middle of the morning. | We're getting towards winter and it's getting dark earlier.
learner_examples: If I [had] told somebody fifty years ago that women w[ould] have leading political positions towards the end of the century, he or she would have most probably considered [me] as being mad. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German)

definition: for the purpose of buying or achieving something
dictionary_examples: I'm saving up to buy a car, and Dad has given me some money towards it. | Would you like to make a contribution towards a present for Linda? | The work that students do during the term counts towards their final grade.
learner_examples: I hope that these recommendations will go a long way towards improving your museum and having satisfied visitors. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

definition: on

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: Upon her head she wore a black velvet hat. | Please report to the reception desk upon arrival.
candidate_match.learner_examples: He answered with a smile upon his face, 'As I just told everybody else, you will have the results by the end of June.' (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

dictionary_examples: Upon her head she wore a black velvet hat. | Please report to the reception desk upon arrival.
learner_examples: He answered with a smile upon his face, 'As I just told everybody else, you will have the results by the end of June.' (First Certificate in English; B2; Danish)

definition: using a particular machine, system or person to send or recieve something
dictionary_examples: Reports are coming in via satellite. | I only found out about it via my sister.
learner_examples: I hate shopping via [the] internet. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

definition: below something, or below the surface of something
dictionary_examples: He hid under the bed. | They were standing under a tree. | She was holding a file under her arm. |  She pushed her bag under the table. |  He could only keep his head under the water for a few seconds.
learner_examples: I like my bedroom, because there [is] a table under the window, [and] some pictures on the wall. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic)

definition: having or including something
dictionary_examples: a house with a swimming pool | a woman with brown eyes
learner_examples: I want you to cook rice with fish and olives. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

definition: less than a number, amount, or age
dictionary_examples: All items cost/are under a pound. | You can buy the whole set of DVDs for just under £30. | The discount applies only to children under (the age of) ten. | Under-5s get in free. | If you get under 50%, you've failed the exam.
learner_examples: I saw an advertisement in front of my house: the coffee bar is looking for some waiters aged under 23 years old. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

definition: not having, using, or doing something

candidate_match.definition: not having, using, or doing something
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: I've come out without my umbrella. | You look nice without make-up. | You shouldn't drive for more than three hours without taking/having a break.
candidate_match.learner_examples: I have an exam tomorrow and I cannot study without the folder. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: I've come out without my umbrella. | You look nice without make-up. | You shouldn't drive for more than three hours without taking/having a break.
learner_examples: I have an exam tomorrow and I cannot study without the folder. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

definition: under or below something

candidate_match.dictionary_examples: The tunnel goes right underneath the city. | They found a bomb underneath the car.
candidate_match.learner_examples: She was dressed like a princess, after spending the whole day looking for an appropriate dress, which she finally managed to find underneath her bed. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

dictionary_examples: The tunnel goes right underneath the city. | They found a bomb underneath the car.
learner_examples: She was dressed like a princess, after spending the whole day looking for an appropriate dress, which she finally managed to find underneath her bed. (First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese)

definition: used to say what fills, covers, etc. something
dictionary_examples: a bucket filled with water | She filled the jug with cream.
learner_examples: It was like throwing her into a pool filled with ice. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi)

definition: less than a particular distance from something
dictionary_examples: Two-thirds of Californians live within 15 miles of the coast. | The hotel is within easy reach of the airport.
learner_examples: By the way, [the] receptionist told me that the scenery round the lake is very beautiful and that the Butterfly Farm and the monument shown on your map are within easy reach. (First Certificate in English; B2; German)

definition: not outside the limits of something
dictionary_examples: We came within five points of beating them. | The project was completed well within budget.
learner_examples: Similarly [the] visitor has also shown responsibility to remain within [the] limits of the society he is moving [in], so that he cannot cause any hurt or harm to local culture. (International English Language Testing System; B2; Panjabi)

definition: used to say that one team or person is competing against another
dictionary_examples: Tomorrow's game is Newcastle versus Arsenal.
learner_examples: Starting in chronological order you can see the first game - Argentina versus Germany - which was a revenge for the final competition in the previous World Cup, '88. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

definition: going through or stopping at a place on the way to another place
dictionary_examples: The train to Utrecht goes via Amsterdam.
learner_examples: Two years ago I travel[l]ed to Canada via Italy. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic)

definition: different from someone or something
dictionary_examples: The furniture was unlike anything she had ever seen. | Dan's actually quite nice, unlike his father. | Unlike you, I'm not a great dancer.
learner_examples: In fact the Hotel Astrid is now closed so I had to stay at the Riverside Hotel, [whi]ch offers great savings for students, unlike the Hotel Royal [whi]ch is quite expensive. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

definition: not typical of someone or something
dictionary_examples: It's unlike her to be quiet - was there something wrong?
learner_examples: Over the weeks he was getting more and more exhausted and started reducing [his] hours of work. That was so unlike him. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish)

definition: continuing to happen before a particular time or event and then stopping
dictionary_examples: I'm staying here until the end of June. |  The show will be on until the end of the month. | I was working until past midnight.
learner_examples: I don't go to college every day. I go only on Tuesday until 1.00 p.m. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish)

definition: used to say that people or things are in a place together or are doing something together
dictionary_examples: I was with Sylvia at the time. | He lives with his grandmother. | I'm going to France with a couple of friends. | Ingrid Bergman starred with Humphrey Bogart in the film 'Casablanca'.
learner_examples: On Sunday afternoon, she goes with her husband and her son to the swim[m]ing pool. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian)

definition: as far as
dictionary_examples: Carry on until the traffic lights and then turn right.
learner_examples: You have to [stay on] the train until Charles DE GAULLE Etoile station. (Key English Test; A2; French)

definition: to or in a higher place or position

candidate_match.definition: to or in a higher place or position
candidate_match.dictionary_examples: He ran up the steps. | We followed her up the stairs to a large meeting room.
candidate_match.learner_examples: We r[o]de up the mountain [on] our b[i]kes. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: He ran up the steps. | We followed her up the stairs to a large meeting room.
learner_examples: We r[o]de up the mountain [on] our b[i]kes. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

definition: using something
dictionary_examples: She hit him over the head with a tennis racket. | Fix the two pieces together with glue.
learner_examples: I can print [the] advertisement and tickets with my computer. (Key English Test; A2; French)

definition: used to describe the way someone does something
dictionary_examples: He plays with great skill.
learner_examples: People can do more things and with more energy when [they are] listening to music. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

definition: before a particular period of time has finished
dictionary_examples: The ambulance arrived within 10 minutes. | This product should be eaten within three days.
learner_examples: I will return it to you within four days. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil)

definition: in a particular state or condition
dictionary_examples: The President is under pressure to resign.  | Under no circumstances should the festival become too specialized.
learner_examples: I am used to working under pressure. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

definition: because of something
dictionary_examples: I was shaking with fear. | I can't work with all that noise going on.
learner_examples: It was Tuesday the 13th and the fact that I was very superstitious made me tremble with fear. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

definition: relating to something or someone
dictionary_examples: There's something wrong with the car.
learner_examples: [It]'s such a shame when people use [computers] badly, just for damaging and making things worse, because if there's something wrong with them, almost everything is wrong [with] us too. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

definition: used to compare two things or ideas, especially when you have to choose between them
dictionary_examples: private education versus state education
learner_examples: Mobile phones - fashion versus utility Nowadays, [everywhere] you look, there is someone speaking [on] a mobile phone. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian)

definition: inside an area, group, or system
dictionary_examples: a dispute within the department | There's a pharmacy within the hospital building.
learner_examples: Dear Sir or Madam, I am writing to you, as requested, in order to ensure that the training - whose purpose is to help the staff improve its communications with the other departments within the company - is effective and not just a waste of time. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)
